an3.37:1.1: “On the eighth day of the fortnight, mendicants, the ministers and counselors of the Four Great Kings wander about the world, thinking:
an3.37:1.2: ‘Hopefully most humans are paying due respect to their parents, ascetics and brahmins, honoring the elders in their families, observing the sabbath, staying awake, and making merit.’
an3.37:1.3: And on the fourteenth day of the fortnight, the sons of the Four Great Kings wander about the world, thinking:
an3.37:1.4: ‘Hopefully most humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’
an3.37:1.5: And on the fifteenth day sabbath, the Four Great Kings themselves wander about the world, thinking:
an3.37:1.6: ‘Hopefully most humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’
an3.37:2.1: If only a few humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit,
an3.37:2.2: then the Four Great Kings address the gods of the Thirty-Three, seated together in the Hall of Justice:
an3.37:2.3: ‘Only a few humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’
an3.37:2.4: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three are disappointed, thinking,
an3.37:2.5: ‘The heavenly hosts will dwindle, while the demon hosts will swell!’
an3.37:3.1: But if many humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit,
an3.37:3.2: then the Four Great Kings address the gods of the Thirty-Three, seated together in the Hall of Justice:
an3.37:3.3: ‘Many humans are paying due respect to their parents … and making merit.’
an3.37:3.4: Then the gods of the Thirty-Three are pleased, thinking,
an3.37:3.5: ‘The heavenly hosts will swell, while the demon hosts will dwindle!’
an3.37:4.1: Once upon a time, Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-Three, recited this verse:
an3.37:5.4: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,
an3.37:5.5: and the eighth day of the fortnight,
an3.37:5.6: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’
an3.37:6.1: But that verse was poorly sung by Sakka, lord of gods, not well sung; poorly spoken, not well spoken.
an3.37:6.3: Sakka, lord of gods, is not free of greed, hate, and delusion.
an3.37:7.1: But for a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—it is appropriate to say:
an3.37:8.4: on the fourteenth and the fifteenth days,
an3.37:8.5: and the eighth day of the fortnight,
an3.37:8.6: as well as on the fortnightly special displays.’
an3.37:9.2: Because that mendicant is free of greed, hate, and delusion.”
